abstract.p: Baltimore Museum of Art opens exhibition of furnishings, fashion, art and china associated with 15 presidents, ranging from George Washington to Bill Clinton; photo (M)

block.p: While the United States focuses its attention on the next presidential election, the Baltimore Museum of Art is presenting a collection of furnishings and fashion, art and china associated with 15 residents, ranging from George Washington to Bill Clinton.

Among the highlights of the exhibition, called ''Power, Politics and Style: Art for the Presidents,'' are a study for a posthumous portrait of a pensive John F. Kennedy by Aaron Shikler; a uniform for White House guards, commissioned by Richard M. Nixon and found by critics to be better suited for an operetta; and a Roman-style silver wine jug designed by Thomas Jefferson.

While the United States focuses its attention on the next presidential election, the Baltimore Museum of Art is presenting a collection of furnishings and fashion, art and china associated with 15 residents, ranging from George Washington to Bill Clinton.

Among the highlights of the exhibition, called ''Power, Politics and Style: Art for the Presidents,'' are a study for a posthumous portrait of a pensive John F. Kennedy by Aaron Shikler; a uniform for White House guards, commissioned by Richard M. Nixon and found by critics to be better suited for an operetta; and a Roman-style silver wine jug designed by Thomas Jefferson.
The Clinton period is represented by a photograph of Hillary Rodham Clinton by Annie Leibovitz and a swatch of fabric from a reupholstered Blue Room chair.
Artists whose work is on view include the cabinetmakers William King and Pierre-Antoine Bellange, the architects Pierre-Charles L'Enfant and Charles McKim, and the dress designer Oleg Cassini.

Reproduced for the exhibition are six pieces -- including two chairs and two sofas -- that were part of a 36-piece set commissioned by James Madison and destroyed in the White House fire during the War of 1812.

The Baltimore Museum of Art is on Art Museum Drive at North Charles and 31st Streets; (410) 396-7100; www.artbma.org. General admission: $6 (free Thursday); closed Monday and Tuesday. The exhibition runs until Jan. 7, 13 days before Inauguration Day.
